Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in approving the citizenship application by failing to clearly state the residency test applied
Application_Facts: Respondent had 1403 days of physical presence but lacked detailed documentation; approval based on credibility without explicit residency test analysis
Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside and case remanded for redetermination by a different Citizenship Judge
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Citizenship Judge's decision
Court_Ruling: The Citizenship Judge's decision was unreasonable due to lack of clarity on the test applied
Defendant_Behavior: Failed to provide detailed documentation supporting residency claim
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient justification and failure to apply proper legal test under the Citizenship Act
Assessment_Factor: Credibility of applicant, physical presence duration, adherence to Koo (Re) factors
Procedural_Issue: Failure to articulate the residency test used in the decision

Evidence_Used: Self-reported residency information, limited documentary evidence
Application_Basis: Residency based on 1095-day requirement within reference period

Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of detailed documentation to support residency claim
Outcome: Application initially approved, then decision set aside on judicial review
Harm_Assessment: Risk of improper citizenship grant due to inadequate legal analysis
Cause_Description: Dispute over whether the residency requirement was met under the Citizenship Act
